segment.source: 4742(S) A computer account was changed.
segment.target: 4742(S) A computer account was changed.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 4742(S) A computer account was changed.
segment.target: Describes security event 4742(S) A computer account was changed.

segment.source: 4742(S): A computer account was changed.
segment.target: 4742(S): A computer account was changed.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event generates every time a computer object is changed.
segment.target: This event generates every time a computer object is changed.

segment.source: This event generates only on domain controllers.
segment.target: This event generates only on domain controllers.

segment.source: You might see the same values for SubjectSecurity ID and Computer Account That Was ChangedSecurity ID in this event.
segment.target: You might see the same values for SubjectSecurity ID and Computer Account That Was ChangedSecurity ID in this event.

segment.source: This usually happens when you reboot a computer after adding it to the domain (the change takes effect after the reboot).
segment.target: This usually happens when you reboot a computer after adding it to the domain (the change takes effect after the reboot).

segment.source: For each change, a separate 4742 event will be generated.
segment.target: For each change, a separate 4742 event will be generated.

segment.source: Some changes do not invoke a 4742 event, for example, changes made using Active Directory Users and Computers management console in Managed By tab in computer account properties.
segment.target: Some changes do not invoke a 4742 event, for example, changes made using Active Directory Users and Computers management console in Managed By tab in computer account properties.

segment.source: You might see this event without any changes inside, that is, where all Changed Attributes apear as “-“.
segment.target: You might see this event without any changes inside, that is, where all Changed Attributes apear as “-“.

segment.source: This usually happens when a change is made to an attribute that is not listed in the event.
segment.target: This usually happens when a change is made to an attribute that is not listed in the event.

segment.source: In this case there is no way to determine which attribute was changed.
segment.target: In this case there is no way to determine which attribute was changed.

segment.source: For example, this would happen if you change the Description of a group object using the Active Directory Users and Computers administrative console.
segment.target: For example, this would happen if you change the Description of a group object using the Active Directory Users and Computers administrative console.

segment.source: Also, if the discretionary access control list (DACL) is changed, a 4742 event will generate, but all attributes will be “-“.
segment.target: Also, if the discretionary access control list (DACL) is changed, a 4742 event will generate, but all attributes will be “-“.

segment.source: Important: If you manually change any user-related setting or attribute, for example if you set the SMARTCARDREQUIRED flag in userAccountControl for the computer account, then the sAMAccountType of the computer account will be changed to NORMALUSERACCOUNT and you will get “4738: A user account was changed” instead of 4742 for this computer account.
segment.target: Important: If you manually change any user-related setting or attribute, for example if you set the SMARTCARDREQUIRED flag in userAccountControl for the computer account, then the sAMAccountType of the computer account will be changed to NORMALUSERACCOUNT and you will get “4738: A user account was changed” instead of 4742 for this computer account.

segment.source: Essentially, the computer account will “become” a user account.
segment.target: Essentially, the computer account will “become” a user account.

segment.source: For NORMALUSERACCOUNT you will always get events from Audit User Account Management subcategory.
segment.target: For NORMALUSERACCOUNT you will always get events from Audit User Account Management subcategory.

segment.source: We strongly recommend that you avoid changing any user-related settings manually for computer objects.
segment.target: We strongly recommend that you avoid changing any user-related settings manually for computer objects.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: Active Directory domain controller.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: Active Directory domain controller.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Subject:
segment.target: Subject:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the “change Computer object” operation.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the “change Computer object” operation.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the “change Computer object” operation.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the “change Computer object” operation.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Computer Account That Was Changed:
segment.target: Computer Account That Was Changed:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of changed computer account.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of changed computer account.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the computer account that was changed.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the computer account that was changed.

segment.source: For example: WIN81$
segment.target: For example: WIN81$

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: domain name of changed computer account.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: domain name of changed computer account.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: Changed Attributes:
segment.target: Changed Attributes:

segment.source: Note If attribute was not changed it will have “-“ value.
segment.target: Note If attribute was not changed it will have “-“ value.

segment.source: SAM Account Name Type = UnicodeString: logon name for account used to support clients and servers from previous versions of Windows (pre-Windows 2000 logon name).
segment.target: SAM Account Name Type = UnicodeString: logon name for account used to support clients and servers from previous versions of Windows (pre-Windows 2000 logon name).

segment.source: If the value of sAMAccountName attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of sAMAccountName attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: For example: WIN8$.
segment.target: For example: WIN8$.

segment.source: Display Name Type = UnicodeString: it is a name displayed in the address book for a particular account (typically – user account).
segment.target: Display Name Type = UnicodeString: it is a name displayed in the address book for a particular account (typically – user account).

segment.source: This is usually the combination of the user's first name, middle initial, and last name.
segment.target: This is usually the combination of the user's first name, middle initial, and last name.

segment.source: For computer objects, it is optional, and typically is not set.
segment.target: For computer objects, it is optional, and typically is not set.

segment.source: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.
segment.target: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.

segment.source: If the value of displayName attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of displayName attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: User Principal Name Type = UnicodeString: internet-style login name for the account, based on the Internet standard RFC 822.
segment.target: User Principal Name Type = UnicodeString: internet-style login name for the account, based on the Internet standard RFC 822.

segment.source: By convention this should map to the account's email name.
segment.target: By convention this should map to the account's email name.

segment.source: If the value of userPrincipalName attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of userPrincipalName attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: For computer objects, it is optional, and typically is not set.
segment.target: For computer objects, it is optional, and typically is not set.

segment.source: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.
segment.target: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.

segment.source: Home Directory Type = UnicodeString: user's home directory.
segment.target: Home Directory Type = UnicodeString: user's home directory.

segment.source: If homeDrive attribute is set and specifies a drive letter, homeDirectory should be a UNC path.
segment.target: If homeDrive attribute is set and specifies a drive letter, homeDirectory should be a UNC path.

segment.source: The path must be a network UNC of the form ServerShareDirectory.
segment.target: The path must be a network UNC of the form ServerShareDirectory.

segment.source: If the value of homeDirectory attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of homeDirectory attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: For computer objects, it is optional, and typically is not set.
segment.target: For computer objects, it is optional, and typically is not set.

segment.source: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.
segment.target: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.

segment.source: Home Drive Type = UnicodeString: specifies the drive letter to which to map the UNC path specified by homeDirectory account’s attribute.
segment.target: Home Drive Type = UnicodeString: specifies the drive letter to which to map the UNC path specified by homeDirectory account’s attribute.

segment.source: The drive letter must be specified in the form “DRIVELETTER:”.
segment.target: The drive letter must be specified in the form “DRIVELETTER:”.

segment.source: For example – “H:”.
segment.target: For example – “H:”.

segment.source: If the value of homeDrive attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of homeDrive attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: For computer objects, it is optional, and typically is not set.
segment.target: For computer objects, it is optional, and typically is not set.

segment.source: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.
segment.target: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.

segment.source: Script Path Type = UnicodeString: specifies the path of the account’s logon script.
segment.target: Script Path Type = UnicodeString: specifies the path of the account’s logon script.

segment.source: If the value of scriptPath attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of scriptPath attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: For computer objects, it is optional, and typically is not set.
segment.target: For computer objects, it is optional, and typically is not set.

segment.source: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.
segment.target: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.

segment.source: Profile Path Type = UnicodeString: specifies a path to the account's profile.
segment.target: Profile Path Type = UnicodeString: specifies a path to the account's profile.

segment.source: This value can be a null string, a local absolute path, or a UNC path.
segment.target: This value can be a null string, a local absolute path, or a UNC path.

segment.source: If the value of profilePath attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of profilePath attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: For computer objects, it is optional, and typically is not set.
segment.target: For computer objects, it is optional, and typically is not set.

segment.source: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.
segment.target: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.

segment.source: User Workstations Type = UnicodeString: contains the list of NetBIOS or DNS names of the computers from which the user can logon.
segment.target: User Workstations Type = UnicodeString: contains the list of NetBIOS or DNS names of the computers from which the user can logon.

segment.source: Each computer name is separated by a comma.
segment.target: Each computer name is separated by a comma.

segment.source: The name of a computer is the sAMAccountName property of a computer object.
segment.target: The name of a computer is the sAMAccountName property of a computer object.

segment.source: If the value of userWorkstations attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of userWorkstations attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: For computer objects, it is optional, and typically is not set.
segment.target: For computer objects, it is optional, and typically is not set.

segment.source: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.
segment.target: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.

segment.source: Password Last Set Type = UnicodeString: last time the account’s password was modified.
segment.target: Password Last Set Type = UnicodeString: last time the account’s password was modified.

segment.source: If the value of pwdLastSet attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of pwdLastSet attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: This value will be changed, for example, after manual computer account reset action or automatically every 30 days by default for computer objects.
segment.target: This value will be changed, for example, after manual computer account reset action or automatically every 30 days by default for computer objects.

segment.source: Account Expires Type = UnicodeString: the date when the account expires.
segment.target: Account Expires Type = UnicodeString: the date when the account expires.

segment.source: If the value of accountExpires attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of accountExpires attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: For computer objects, it is optional, and typically is not set.
segment.target: For computer objects, it is optional, and typically is not set.

segment.source: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.
segment.target: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.

segment.source: Primary Group ID Type = UnicodeString: Relative Identifier (RID) of computer’s object primary group.
segment.target: Primary Group ID Type = UnicodeString: Relative Identifier (RID) of computer’s object primary group.

segment.source:
Note
Relative identifier (RID) is a variable length number that is assigned to objects at creation and becomes part of the object's Security Identifier (SID) that uniquely identifies an account or group within a domain.
segment.target:
Note
Relative identifier (RID) is a variable length number that is assigned to objects at creation and becomes part of the object's Security Identifier (SID) that uniquely identifies an account or group within a domain.

segment.source: This field will contain some value if computer’s object primary group was changed.
segment.target: This field will contain some value if computer’s object primary group was changed.

segment.source: You can change computer’s primary group using Active Directory Users and Computers management console in the Member Of tab of computer object properties.
segment.target: You can change computer’s primary group using Active Directory Users and Computers management console in the Member Of tab of computer object properties.

segment.source: You will see a RID of new primary group as a field value.
segment.target: You will see a RID of new primary group as a field value.

segment.source: For example, 515 (Domain Computers) for workstations, is a default primary group.
segment.target: For example, 515 (Domain Computers) for workstations, is a default primary group.

segment.source: Typical Primary Group values for computer accounts:
segment.target: Typical Primary Group values for computer accounts:

segment.source: 516 (Domain Controllers) – for domain controllers.
segment.target: 516 (Domain Controllers) – for domain controllers.

segment.source: 521 (Read-only Domain Controllers) – read-only domain controllers (RODC).
segment.target: 521 (Read-only Domain Controllers) – read-only domain controllers (RODC).

segment.source: 515 (Domain Computers) – servers and workstations.
segment.target: 515 (Domain Computers) – servers and workstations.

segment.source: See this article https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/kb/243330 for more information.
segment.target: See this article https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/kb/243330 for more information.

segment.source: If the value of primaryGroupID attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of primaryGroupID attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: AllowedToDelegateTo Type = UnicodeString: the list of SPNs to which this account can present delegated credentials.
segment.target: AllowedToDelegateTo Type = UnicodeString: the list of SPNs to which this account can present delegated credentials.

segment.source: Can be changed using Active Directory Users and Computers management console in Delegation tab of computer account.
segment.target: Can be changed using Active Directory Users and Computers management console in Delegation tab of computer account.

segment.source: If the SPNs list on Delegation tab of a computer account was changed, you will see the new SPNs list in AllowedToDelegateTo field (note that you will see the new list instead of changes) of this event.
segment.target: If the SPNs list on Delegation tab of a computer account was changed, you will see the new SPNs list in AllowedToDelegateTo field (note that you will see the new list instead of changes) of this event.

segment.source: This is an example of AllowedToDelegateTo:
segment.target: This is an example of AllowedToDelegateTo:

segment.source: dcom/WIN2012
segment.target: dcom/WIN2012

segment.source: dcom/WIN2012.contoso.local
segment.target: dcom/WIN2012.contoso.local

segment.source: If the value of msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: The value can be value not set, for example, if delegation was disabled.
segment.target: The value can be value not set, for example, if delegation was disabled.

segment.source:
Note
Service Principal Name (SPN) is the name by which a client uniquely identifies an instance of a service.
segment.target:
Note
Service Principal Name (SPN) is the name by which a client uniquely identifies an instance of a service.

segment.source: If you install multiple instances of a service on computers throughout a forest, each instance must have its own SPN.
segment.target: If you install multiple instances of a service on computers throughout a forest, each instance must have its own SPN.

segment.source: A given service instance can have multiple SPNs if there are multiple names that clients might use for authentication.
segment.target: A given service instance can have multiple SPNs if there are multiple names that clients might use for authentication.

segment.source: For example, an SPN always includes the name of the host computer on which the service instance is running, so a service instance might register an SPN for each name or alias of its host.
segment.target: For example, an SPN always includes the name of the host computer on which the service instance is running, so a service instance might register an SPN for each name or alias of its host.

segment.source: Old UAC Value Type = UnicodeString: specifies flags that control password, lockout, disable/enable, script, and other behavior for the user or computer account.
segment.target: Old UAC Value Type = UnicodeString: specifies flags that control password, lockout, disable/enable, script, and other behavior for the user or computer account.

segment.source: This parameter contains the previous value of userAccountControl attribute of computer object.
segment.target: This parameter contains the previous value of userAccountControl attribute of computer object.

segment.source: New UAC Value Type = UnicodeString: specifies flags that control password, lockout, disable/enable, script, and other behavior for the user or computer account.
segment.target: New UAC Value Type = UnicodeString: specifies flags that control password, lockout, disable/enable, script, and other behavior for the user or computer account.

segment.source: If the value of userAccountControl attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of userAccountControl attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: To decode this value, you can go through the property value definitions in the “Table 7.
segment.target: To decode this value, you can go through the property value definitions in the “Table 7.

segment.source: User’s or Computer’s account UAC flags.”
segment.target: User’s or Computer’s account UAC flags.”

segment.source: from largest to smallest.
segment.target: from largest to smallest.

segment.source: Compare each property value to the flags value in the event.
segment.target: Compare each property value to the flags value in the event.

segment.source: If the flags value in the event is greater than or equal to the property value, then the property is "set" and applies to that event.
segment.target: If the flags value in the event is greater than or equal to the property value, then the property is "set" and applies to that event.

segment.source: Subtract the property value from the flags value in the event and note that the flag applies and then go on to the next flag.
segment.target: Subtract the property value from the flags value in the event and note that the flag applies and then go on to the next flag.

segment.source: Here's an example: Flags value from event: 0x15
segment.target: Here's an example: Flags value from event: 0x15

segment.source: Decoding:
segment.target: Decoding:

segment.source: • PASSWDNOTREQD 0x0020
segment.target: • PASSWDNOTREQD 0x0020

segment.source: • LOCKOUT 0x0010
segment.target: • LOCKOUT 0x0010

segment.source: • HOMEDIRREQUIRED 0x0008
segment.target: • HOMEDIRREQUIRED 0x0008

segment.source: • (undeclared) 0x0004
segment.target: • (undeclared) 0x0004

segment.source: • ACCOUNTDISABLE 0x0002
segment.target: • ACCOUNTDISABLE 0x0002

segment.source: • SCRIPT 0x0001
segment.target: • SCRIPT 0x0001

segment.source: 0x0020 0x15, so PASSWDNOTREQD does not apply to this event
segment.target: 0x0020 0x15, so PASSWDNOTREQD does not apply to this event

segment.source: 0x10 0x15, so LOCKOUT applies to this event.
segment.target: 0x10 0x15, so LOCKOUT applies to this event.

segment.source: 0x4 0x5, so the undeclared value is set.
segment.target: 0x4 0x5, so the undeclared value is set.

segment.source: We'll pretend it doesn't mean anything.
segment.target: We'll pretend it doesn't mean anything.

segment.source: 0x2 0x1, so ACCOUNTDISABLE does not apply to this event
segment.target: 0x2 0x1, so ACCOUNTDISABLE does not apply to this event

segment.source: 0x1 = 0x1, so SCRIPT applies to this event.
segment.target: 0x1 = 0x1, so SCRIPT applies to this event.

segment.source: 0x1 - 0x1 = 0x0, we're done.
segment.target: 0x1 - 0x1 = 0x0, we're done.

segment.source: So this UAC flags value decodes to: LOCKOUT and SCRIPT
segment.target: So this UAC flags value decodes to: LOCKOUT and SCRIPT

segment.source: User Account Control Type = UnicodeString: shows the list of changes in userAccountControl attribute.
segment.target: User Account Control Type = UnicodeString: shows the list of changes in userAccountControl attribute.

segment.source: You will see a line of text for each change.
segment.target: You will see a line of text for each change.

segment.source: See possible values in here: “Table 7.
segment.target: See possible values in here: “Table 7.

segment.source: User’s or Computer’s account UAC flags.”.
segment.target: User’s or Computer’s account UAC flags.”.

segment.source: In the “User Account Control field text” column, you can see text that will be displayed in the User Account Control field in 4742 event.
segment.target: In the “User Account Control field text” column, you can see text that will be displayed in the User Account Control field in 4742 event.

segment.source: User Parameters Type = UnicodeString: if you change any setting using Active Directory Users and Computers management console in Dial-in tab of computer’s account properties, then you will see value changed, but not displayed in this field.
segment.target: User Parameters Type = UnicodeString: if you change any setting using Active Directory Users and Computers management console in Dial-in tab of computer’s account properties, then you will see value changed, but not displayed in this field.

segment.source: SID History Type = UnicodeString: contains previous SIDs used for the object if the object was moved from another domain.
segment.target: SID History Type = UnicodeString: contains previous SIDs used for the object if the object was moved from another domain.

segment.source: Whenever an object is moved from one domain to another, a new SID is created and becomes the objectSID.
segment.target: Whenever an object is moved from one domain to another, a new SID is created and becomes the objectSID.

segment.source: The previous SID is added to the sIDHistory property.
segment.target: The previous SID is added to the sIDHistory property.

segment.source: If the value of sIDHistory attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of sIDHistory attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: Logon Hours Type = UnicodeString: hours that the account is allowed to logon to the domain.
segment.target: Logon Hours Type = UnicodeString: hours that the account is allowed to logon to the domain.

segment.source: If the value of logonHours attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of logonHours attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: For computer objects, it is optional, and typically is not set.
segment.target: For computer objects, it is optional, and typically is not set.

segment.source: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.
segment.target: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.

segment.source: DNS Host Name Type = UnicodeString: name of computer account as registered in DNS.
segment.target: DNS Host Name Type = UnicodeString: name of computer account as registered in DNS.

segment.source: If the value of dNSHostName attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of dNSHostName attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: Service Principal Names Type = UnicodeString: The list of SPNs, registered for computer account.
segment.target: Service Principal Names Type = UnicodeString: The list of SPNs, registered for computer account.

segment.source: If the SPN list of a computer account changed, you will see the new SPN list in Service Principal Names field (note that you will see the new list instead of changes).
segment.target: If the SPN list of a computer account changed, you will see the new SPN list in Service Principal Names field (note that you will see the new list instead of changes).

segment.source: If the value of servicePrincipalName attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of servicePrincipalName attribute of computer object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: Here is an example of Service Principal Names field for new domain joined workstation in event 4742 on domain controller, after workstation reboots:
segment.target: Here is an example of Service Principal Names field for new domain joined workstation in event 4742 on domain controller, after workstation reboots:

segment.source: HOST/Win81.contoso.local
segment.target: HOST/Win81.contoso.local

segment.source: RestrictedKrbHost/Win81.contoso.local
segment.target: RestrictedKrbHost/Win81.contoso.local

segment.source: HOST/WIN81
segment.target: HOST/WIN81

segment.source: RestrictedKrbHost/WIN81
segment.target: RestrictedKrbHost/WIN81

segment.source: TERMSRV/Win81.contoso.local
segment.target: TERMSRV/Win81.contoso.local

segment.source: Additional Information:
segment.target: Additional Information:

segment.source: Privileges Type = UnicodeString: the list of user privileges which were used during the operation, for example, SeBackupPrivilege.
segment.target: Privileges Type = UnicodeString: the list of user privileges which were used during the operation, for example, SeBackupPrivilege.

segment.source: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “-”.
segment.target: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “-”.

segment.source: See full list of user privileges in “Table 8.
segment.target: See full list of user privileges in “Table 8.

segment.source: User Privileges.”.
segment.target: User Privileges.”.

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 4742(S): A computer account was changed.
segment.target: For 4742(S): A computer account was changed.

segment.source: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.
segment.target: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.

segment.source: If you have critical domain computer accounts (database servers, domain controllers, administration workstations, and so on) for which you need to monitor each change, monitor this event with the “Computer Account That Was ChangedSecurity ID” that corresponds to the high-value account or accounts.
segment.target: If you have critical domain computer accounts (database servers, domain controllers, administration workstations, and so on) for which you need to monitor each change, monitor this event with the “Computer Account That Was ChangedSecurity ID” that corresponds to the high-value account or accounts.

segment.source: If you have computer accounts for which any change in the services list on the Delegation tab should be monitored, monitor this event when AllowedToDelegateTo is not -.
segment.target: If you have computer accounts for which any change in the services list on the Delegation tab should be monitored, monitor this event when AllowedToDelegateTo is not -.

segment.source: This value means the services list was changed.
segment.target: This value means the services list was changed.

segment.source: Consider whether to track the following fields and values:
segment.target: Consider whether to track the following fields and values:

segment.source: Field and value to track
segment.target: Field and value to track

segment.source: Reason to track
segment.target: Reason to track

segment.source: Display Name is not -
segment.target: Display Name is not -

segment.source: User Principal Name is not -
segment.target: User Principal Name is not -

segment.source: Home Directory is not -
segment.target: Home Directory is not -

segment.source: Home Drive is not -
segment.target: Home Drive is not -

segment.source: Script Path is not -
segment.target: Script Path is not -

segment.source: Profile Path is not -
segment.target: Profile Path is not -

segment.source: User Workstations is not -
segment.target: User Workstations is not -

segment.source: Account Expires is not -
segment.target: Account Expires is not -

segment.source: Logon Hours is not
segment.target: Logon Hours is not

segment.source: Typically these fields are for computer accounts.
segment.target: Typically these fields are for computer accounts.

segment.source: Other values might indicate an anomaly and should be monitored.
segment.target: Other values might indicate an anomaly and should be monitored.

segment.source: Password Last Set changes occur more often than usual
segment.target: Password Last Set changes occur more often than usual

segment.source: Changes that are more frequent than the default (typically once a month) might indicate an anomaly or attack.
segment.target: Changes that are more frequent than the default (typically once a month) might indicate an anomaly or attack.

segment.source: Primary Group ID is not 516, 521, or 515
segment.target: Primary Group ID is not 516, 521, or 515

segment.source: Typically, the Primary Group ID value is one of the following:
segment.target: Typically, the Primary Group ID value is one of the following:

segment.source: 516 for domain controllers
segment.target: 516 for domain controllers

segment.source: 521 for read only domain controllers (RODCs)
segment.target: 521 for read only domain controllers (RODCs)

segment.source: 515 for servers and workstations (domain computers)
segment.target: 515 for servers and workstations (domain computers)

segment.source: Other values should be monitored.
segment.target: Other values should be monitored.

segment.source: For computer accounts for which the services list (on the Delegation tab) should not be empty: AllowedToDelegateTo is marked value not set
segment.target: For computer accounts for which the services list (on the Delegation tab) should not be empty: AllowedToDelegateTo is marked value not set

segment.source: If AllowedToDelegateTo is marked value not set on computers that previously had a services list (on the Delegation tab), it means the list was cleared.
segment.target: If AllowedToDelegateTo is marked value not set on computers that previously had a services list (on the Delegation tab), it means the list was cleared.

segment.source: SID History is not -
segment.target: SID History is not -

segment.source: This field will always be set to - unless the account was migrated from another domain.
segment.target: This field will always be set to - unless the account was migrated from another domain.

segment.source: Consider whether to track the following account control flags:
segment.target: Consider whether to track the following account control flags:

segment.source: User account control flag to track
segment.target: User account control flag to track

segment.source: Information about the flag
segment.target: Information about the flag

segment.source: 'Password Not Required' – Enabled
segment.target: 'Password Not Required' – Enabled

segment.source: Should not be set for computer accounts.
segment.target: Should not be set for computer accounts.

segment.source: Computer accounts typically require a password by default, except manually created computer objects.
segment.target: Computer accounts typically require a password by default, except manually created computer objects.

segment.source: 'Encrypted Text Password Allowed' – Enabled
segment.target: 'Encrypted Text Password Allowed' – Enabled

segment.source: Should not be set for computer accounts.
segment.target: Should not be set for computer accounts.

segment.source: By default, it will not be set, and it cannot be set in the account properties in Active Directory Users and Computers.
segment.target: By default, it will not be set, and it cannot be set in the account properties in Active Directory Users and Computers.

segment.source: 'Server Trust Account' – Enabled
segment.target: 'Server Trust Account' – Enabled

segment.source: Should be enabled only for domain controllers.
segment.target: Should be enabled only for domain controllers.

segment.source: 'Server Trust Account' – Disabled
segment.target: 'Server Trust Account' – Disabled

segment.source: Should not be disabled for domain controllers.
segment.target: Should not be disabled for domain controllers.

segment.source: 'Don't Expire Password' – Enabled
segment.target: 'Don't Expire Password' – Enabled

segment.source: Should not be enabled for computer accounts, because the password automatically changes every 30 days by default.
segment.target: Should not be enabled for computer accounts, because the password automatically changes every 30 days by default.

segment.source: For computer accounts, this flag cannot be set in the account properties in Active Directory Users and Computers.
segment.target: For computer accounts, this flag cannot be set in the account properties in Active Directory Users and Computers.

segment.source: 'Smartcard Required' – Enabled
segment.target: 'Smartcard Required' – Enabled

segment.source: Should not be enabled for computer accounts.
segment.target: Should not be enabled for computer accounts.

segment.source: 'Trusted For Delegation' – Enabled
segment.target: 'Trusted For Delegation' – Enabled

segment.source: Means that Kerberos Constraint or Unconstraint delegation was enabled for the computer account.
segment.target: Means that Kerberos Constraint or Unconstraint delegation was enabled for the computer account.

segment.source: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.
segment.target: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.

segment.source: 'Trusted For Delegation' – Disabled
segment.target: 'Trusted For Delegation' – Disabled

segment.source: Means that Kerberos Constraint or Unconstraint delegation was disabled for the computer account.
segment.target: Means that Kerberos Constraint or Unconstraint delegation was disabled for the computer account.

segment.source: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.
segment.target: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.

segment.source: Also, if you have a list of computer accounts for which delegation is critical and should not be disabled, monitor this for those accounts.
segment.target: Also, if you have a list of computer accounts for which delegation is critical and should not be disabled, monitor this for those accounts.

segment.source: 'Trusted To Authenticate For Delegation' – Enabled
segment.target: 'Trusted To Authenticate For Delegation' – Enabled

segment.source: Means that Protocol Transition delegation was enabled for the computer account.
segment.target: Means that Protocol Transition delegation was enabled for the computer account.

segment.source: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.
segment.target: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.

segment.source: 'Trusted To Authenticate For Delegation' – Disabled
segment.target: 'Trusted To Authenticate For Delegation' – Disabled

segment.source: Means that Protocol Transition delegation was disabled for the computer account.
segment.target: Means that Protocol Transition delegation was disabled for the computer account.

segment.source: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.
segment.target: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.

segment.source: Also, if you have a list of computer accounts for which delegation is critical and should not be disabled, monitor this for those accounts.
segment.target: Also, if you have a list of computer accounts for which delegation is critical and should not be disabled, monitor this for those accounts.

segment.source: 'Not Delegated' – Enabled
segment.target: 'Not Delegated' – Enabled

segment.source: Means that Account is sensitive and cannot be delegated was selected for the computer account.
segment.target: Means that Account is sensitive and cannot be delegated was selected for the computer account.

segment.source: For computer accounts, this flag cannot be set using the graphical interface.
segment.target: For computer accounts, this flag cannot be set using the graphical interface.

segment.source: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.
segment.target: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.

segment.source: 'Use DES Key Only' – Enabled
segment.target: 'Use DES Key Only' – Enabled

segment.source: Should not be enabled for computer accounts.
segment.target: Should not be enabled for computer accounts.

segment.source: For computer accounts, it cannot be set in the account properties in Active Directory Users and Computers.
segment.target: For computer accounts, it cannot be set in the account properties in Active Directory Users and Computers.

segment.source: 'Don't Require Preauth' - Enabled
segment.target: 'Don't Require Preauth' - Enabled

segment.source: Should not be enabled for computer accounts.
segment.target: Should not be enabled for computer accounts.

segment.source: For computer accounts, it cannot be set in the account properties in Active Directory Users and Computers.
segment.target: For computer accounts, it cannot be set in the account properties in Active Directory Users and Computers.
